cab.content: THIS DOCUMENT IS THE PROPERTY OF HIS BRITANNIC MAJESTY'S GOVERNMENTPrinted for the War Cabinet. July 1940.SECRET.Copy No. 42W.M. (40)215th Conclusions.TO BE KEPT UNDER LOCK AND KEY.It is requested that special care may be taken toensure the secrecy of this document.WAR CABINET 215 (40).CONCLUSIONS of a Meeting of the War Cabinet held at 10 Downing Street,S.W. 1, on Tuesday, July 30, 1940, at 12-30 p.m.Present:The Right Hon. Winston S. Churchill, M.P., Prime Minister (in the Chair).The Right Hon. C. R. Attlee, M.P., The Right Hon. Viscount Halifax,Lord Privy Seal. Secretary of State for ForeignAffairs.The Right Hon. A. Greenwood, M.P.,Minister without Portfolio.The following were also present :Captain the Right Hon. H. D.Margesson, M.P., parliamentary secretary to the Treasury (Item 1).Sir Edward Bridges, Secretary.Contents.minute no.1Page17421741741743JapanSpainDr. Negrin.[21577] Parliament.ProposedSecret session on ForeignAffairs.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 214thConclusions,Minute 1.)Aliens.(previous reference:W.M. (40) 209thConclusions,Minute 13.)1. The Prime Minister read to the War Cabinet the statement which he proposed to make in the House of Commons that afternoon.He proposed, after setting out the pros and cons, to leave it entirely to the House to settle by a free vote whether the Debate on ForeignAffairs should be held in public or in secret.The War Cabinet approved the Statement.2. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs referred to theAdvisory Committee on Aliens, the establishment of which had beenapproved by the War Cabinet on the 22nd July.After discussion, the War Cabinet approved the following proposals in regard to the personnel of the Committee : The Chairmanship should be offered to Lord Lytton, or, shouldhe be unable to serve, to Lord Willingdon. (Lord Cranborne on grounds of health had declined the Chairmanship, but was willingto serve as a member.)Lady Eeading and Mr. N. Maclean, M.P., should be invitedto be members of the Committee.Japan. 3. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs read to the War(Previous Cabinet telegram No. 1360 (R) from Sir Robert Craigie (Tokyo)reference: reporting the interview which he had had with the JapaneseW.M. (40) 214th Minister for Foreign Affairs in regard to the arrest of BritishConclusions, subjects in Japan.Minute 3.) The Foreign Secretary reported that he had had an interview with the Japanese Ambassador on the same subject.The Foreign Secretary suggested that, if within two or three days matters were not moving towards the release of the Britishsubjects who had been arrested in Japan, we should proceed, as ameasure of reprisal, to seize ten or twelve Japanese subjects, eitherhere or in the Far East. As a first step he would ascertain sir robert Craigie's views on this suggestion, and he would report further to the War Cabinet before taking action on these lines.The War Cabinet took note of the Foreign Secretary'sstatement.Spain. 4. The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs reminded theDr. Negrin. War Cabinet that he had been invited, in conjunction with the(Previous Lord Privy Seal, to consider what steps should be taken to inducereference: Dr. Negrin and other anti-Franco leaders to leave EnglandW.M. (40) 191st voluntarily. The United States Government had refused to grantConclusions, a visa to Dr. Negrin, and it was now proposed to encourage him to minute 7.) ' go to Mexico.In discussion, it was pointed out that Dr. Negrin might notbe willing to go to Mexico, and that the Spanish Government seemedto be less concerned about his presence in this country than whenthe matter had first been raised.The War Cabinet agreed that, if Dr. Negrin was willing to goto Mexico, this would be a solution of the difficulty. If, however,he was unwilling to go, the matter should not be pressed. In this event, if the Spanish Government returned to the charge, we should say that we had suggested that Dr. Negrin should go to another country, but that the country in question had not been willingto receive him; and we should remind the Spanish Government that dr. Negrin was not allowed to engage in any political activity while in this country.Richmond Terrace, S. W. 1,July 30, 1940.
